title: yrExcel
text:
About this book
This book explains how to use Microsoft Excel.
There are many different versions of Excel. This material aims to cover the basic ideas that are generically applicable to most recent versions of Microsoft Excel. The text focuses on Excel 365 (circa 2024). However, the vast majority of this material applies to other versions of Excel as well.
Note that, other than Microsoft Excel, there exist other “spreadsheet” programs and online offerings that are very similar to Excel in many ways. Some of these other offerings include those listed below.

Google Sheets: https://www.google.com/sheets/about/
Libre Office: https://www.libreoffice.org/
Apache Office: https://www.openoffice.org/

While, much of the material presented here will apply to these other spreadsheet programs, some of the material will not. Most significantly, there are numerous functions that will work in Microsoft Excel but not in some of these other programs.

title: 1  Getting Around and Entering Data
text:
Terminology

worksheet

The contents of each “tab” is known as a “worksheet”

workbook

An entire Excel file is known as a “workbook”

cell

A single “box” is known as a “cell”

1.2 How to enter information into cells

Terminology

The “formula bar” at the top of a worksheet shows the contents of the currently selected cell.























Press ESC to cancel changes
If you are typing in a cell and want to cancel your changes, just press ESC.

title: 3  Selecting cells
text:
When you (single) click on a cell you have “selected” it. For example if you click on a cell and press ctrl-b (windows) or cmd-b (mac) you will make the contents of that cell bold.
However, it it possible to “select” multiple cells at once. That way you can apply formatting changes to multiple cells at the same time. There are two ways to select multiple cells,

“shift click” to select contiguous cells
“ctrl-click” (win) or “cmd-click” (mac) to select non-contiguous cells

see below for more info.

using shift to select several cells
You can also select several cells. For example, if you the following:

(single) click on a cell
then press shift-arrowKey (where arrowKey is one of the arrow keys, i.e. up-arrow, down-arrow, left-arrow or right-arrow) You will notice that several cells get selected at once.

If you then do something, it will affect all of those cells at once. For example, if you first select several cells and then press ctrl-b (windows) or cmd-b (mac) you will make the contents of all of the cells that you selected bold.


using ctrl (windows) or cmd (mac) to select several cells
Alternatively if you press the ctrl (windows) or cmd (mac) keys while simultaneously clicking on different cells, you can select several non-contiguous cells.
Similarly if you press ctlr (win) or cmd (mac) and you click-and-drag your mouse you will select several different “ranges” of cells.
Then anything you do (e.g. press ctrl-b or cmd-b) will affect all of those cells.


other ways to select cells

4.5 “Formulas View” vs “Values View”

press ctrl-` (win) or cmd-` (mac) to “toggle” (i.e. switch between) “formulas view” and “values view”
(NOTE - the ` key is usually found under the ESC key. The ` symbol is usually found on the same key as the tilde ie. ~)

title: 5  Different types of cell references (e.g. A1, $A$1, A$1, $A1, 1:1 A:A, etc)
text:
5.1 Dragging cells
It gets very tedious to copy cells one at a time. To make your life easier, you can copy the cells automatically. To do so:
crumbs: 5  Different types of cell references (e.g. A1, $A$1, A$1, $A1, 1:1 A:A, etc)

title: 5  Different types of cell references (e.g. A1, $A$1, A$1, $A1, 1:1 A:A, etc)
text:
click on a cell
point your cursor to the “dot” that appears in the bottom right hand corner of the selected cell. When you are pointing at the “dot”, the cursor will change from a white + sign to a black + sign.
Click on the “dot” and drag down (or up/right/left). As you drag the mouse, the formula will be copied to the adjacent cells.
To automatically drag the formula down to all the rows in a column of a table, simply double-click on the “dot” instead of dragging the “dot”.
crumbs: 5  Different types of cell references (e.g. A1, $A$1, A$1, $A1, 1:1 A:A, etc)

title: 5  Different types of cell references (e.g. A1, $A$1, A$1, $A1, 1:1 A:A, etc)
section: 5.3 References to entire rows or columns (eg 1:1, A:A, etc.)
text:
5.3 References to entire rows or columns (eg 1:1, A:A, etc.)





















References to several rows or columns:




You can also refer to several rows or columns. For example:





the formula =sum(2:4) will sum the entire contents of rows 2,3 and 4
the formula =sum(C:F) will sum the entire contents of columns C,D,E and F










5.4 References to cells on other worksheets (e.g. sheet1!A1)










NOTE




If a sheet name contains a space, then you must surround the sheet name ‘with apostrophes’. For example, the formula:





=sum(‘jan finances’!A1:C3)





refers to the range A1:C3 on the sheet named “jan finances”. This formula can be on any sheet in the entire Excel file.
crumbs: 5  Different types of cell references (e.g. A1, $A$1, A$1, $A1, 1:1 A:A, etc)

title: 14  Sorting Data and working with Tables
text: 14.1 Use data tab to sort
crumbs: 14  Sorting Data and working with Tables

title: 14  Sorting Data and working with Tables
text:
Highlight the range for your data.
On the “Data” tab click the “Sort” button.
If the data contains column headers, check “My data has headers”.
Fill out the rest of the info for which columns to sort on and in which order.
click OK
crumbs: 14  Sorting Data and working with Tables

title: 14  Sorting Data and working with Tables
text:
14.2 Excel Tables
See this video for an overview of Excel tables: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-alMsXBF2D4&t=20s

Covert a range to a table

Click inside your data (or highlight the range)
On the “Insert” tab click “Table”
If the data contains column headers, check “My data has headers”.
Click OK
To change the look of the table, click inside the table and then click on the “Table Design” tab.
You can give a name to the table on this tab where it says “Table name” (in the upper left hand corner of the ribbon). The name of the table will be useful later.



Sorting/Filtering rows

Use the buttons at the top of the columns to sort and/or filter the rows based on the values in the columns.
If you want to sort on multiple columns, apply the sorts in the reverse order of what you want the final order to be.



Convert a table back to a “normal” range
To convert the table back to a “normal” cell range,

click inside the table
click on the “Table Design” tab then click on “Convert to Range”.
Note that the formatting (eg. colors) will not change back. You will need to reformat the colors as you would format any other range. The “format painter” button on the “Home” tab could be helpful to copy the format of another cell. To use the format painter button:

click on a cell whose format you want to copy
click on the “Format Painter” button on the Home tab
Click and drag over the cells that you want to copy the format to.
crumbs: 14  Sorting Data and working with Tables

title: 16  Tips for working with formulas
text:
16.1 show-formulas button
It can be very helpful to see all the formulas in your spreadsheet at once.
To so, on the “Formulas” tab, press the “Show Formulas” button. Note that this displays what Excel actually stores as opposed to the values that Excel calculates. For this reason, when looking at the spreadsheet in the “formulas” view, dates will display as “serial numbers” instead of actual dates.
If you press the button again, the spreadsheet will revert back to showing the calculated values. We say that the button “toggles” between showing the formulas (AKA the “formulas view”) and showing the values (AKA the “values view”).
You can also press the following hotkey to toggle between formulas and values:
Windows: ctrl-`
Mac: Option+Command+`
Note that the ` is NOT the apostrophe, it is the back-tick or “accent” character. It is on the same key as the ~ character. On most american keyboards it is right under the ESC key.
crumbs: 16  Tips for working with formulas

title: 16  Tips for working with formulas
text:
16.2 Working with complex formulas
It is often helpful when trying to analyze a complex formula to see the arguments in the formula on multiple lines. You can make the formula bar on top of the Excel window larger by pointing at the bottom edge of the formula bar (the cursor will change to a double-headed-arrow) and then drag down. If you then press Alt-Enter (win) or Ctrl+Option+Enter (mac) you will be able to type the formula on multiple lines.
See the following for an example of writing a complex formula using this technique.
crumbs: 16  Tips for working with formulas

title: 16  Tips for working with formulas
text:
16.3 Lists of different functions
Click on the Formulas tab to see different categories of formulas in drop-down-lists. Click on a category and then click on a particular function to see a window that describes the different arguments for that function. If you click in a textbox for an argument you will see a description of what to enter for that argument. You can fill in each argument by typing or by clicking on the cells with your mouse. When you are done, press OK to see the results.
crumbs: 16  Tips for working with formulas

title: 16  Tips for working with formulas
section: 16.4 Trace Precedents, Trace Dependents, Remove Arrows buttons
text:
16.4 Trace Precedents, Trace Dependents, Remove Arrows buttons
Select a cell (i.e. click on it) that contains a formula. Then on the “Formulas” tab press the Trace Precedents button. You will then see arrows pointing to the cells that are referenced by the formula. If you continue to click this button you will see more arrows that point to 2nd level dependencies, etc.
Select ANY cell. Then click on the “Trace Dependents” button. You will see arrows that point to any cell that references the selected cell. If you keep pressing this button you will see additional arrows drawn to cells that reference those cells, etc.
None oft these arrows affect the way the spreadsheet works. They are simply there to help you understand the spreadsheet.
Click the “Remove Arrows” button to remove all the arrows from the screen.
crumbs: 16  Tips for working with formulas

title: 16  Tips for working with formulas
text:
16.5 Evaluate formula button
It can be helpful to see step by step how a formula is calculated. To so, select a cell that contains a formula (i.e. click on the cell). Then on the “Formulas” tab, press the “Evaluate Formula” button. You will see a window open up that shows the formula with part of the formula underlined. Click on the “Evaluate” button to evaluate JUST that part of the formula. Keep clicking on the Evaluate button to see step by step how the formula gets processed.
crumbs: 16  Tips for working with formulas

title: 17  “hot-keys”
text:
17.1 The hotkeys
The list of shortcuts below was adapted from https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/excel/excel-shortcuts-pc-mac/
The list below is arranged in order of “importance”. The importance info is based on my personal thoughts. I categorized the importance levels as follows:

title: 17  “hot-keys”
text:
importance
meaning




0
Basic and “obvious” (these are common in many other programs too)


1
Every Excel user should know these


2
Extremely useful to know


3
Helpful, but not so much


4+
Might not be worth memorizing but could be helpful. Can usually do these by pressing buttons.

title: 17  “hot-keys”
text:
17.6 Might not be worth memorizing
Could be helpful for extreme power-users but you can usually do these by pressing buttons or in other ways. For most Excel users, it’s probably not worth memorizing these.
